compoundingBasics.title: Compounding Basics: Start Early
compoundingBasics.description: A quick primer on what compound interest is, why it beats simple interest, and why starting early matters.

intro.title: What is Compound Interest?
intro.content: Compound interest means you earn interest on your original money AND on the interest that money already earned ‚Äî interest on interest. Over time this snowballs.

simpleVsCompound.title: Simple vs Compound
simpleVsCompound.content: Simple interest: interest is only on the original amount (principal). Compound interest: interest is on principal + accumulated interest. Example: R100 at 12% simple = R112 after 1 year. At 12% compounded annually = also R112 after 1 year ‚Äî but keep compounding and compound wins big.

frequencyMatters.title: Compounding Frequency
frequencyMatters.content: More frequent compounding grows faster. R100 at 12% compounded monthly ‚âà R112.68 after 1 year, versus R112 with annual compounding. Same nominal rate, slightly better growth because interest is added more often.

quiz1.title: Quick Check 1
quiz1.question: Which statement best describes compound interest?

A.text: Interest only on the original amount.
A.rationale: That describes simple interest. Compound interest also earns on past interest, not just the original principal.

B.text: Interest on the original amount and on past interest.
B.rationale: Correct. With compounding, previous interest is added to the balance and itself earns interest.

C.rationale: Whether a rate changes or not is separate. Compounding is about earning on principal plus accumulated interest.

D.text: Interest that banks charge only on loans.
D.rationale: Compounding applies to savings and investments too ‚Äî not just loans.

quiz2.title: Quick Check 2
quiz2.question: Two friends each save R200/month at 8% per year. Thabo starts today for 10 years. Naledi waits 5 years, then saves for 5 years. Who ends with more?

A.rationale: Correct. Money invested earlier compounds for longer, which typically beats starting late even with the same monthly amount.

B.rationale: Same monthly amount isn‚Äôt enough ‚Äî Naledi has fewer years of growth. Time in the market matters a lot.

C.text: They end with the same amount.
C.rationale: They won‚Äôt match ‚Äî Thabo‚Äôs money grows for more years due to an earlier start.

D.rationale: Given equal rates and contributions, starting earlier generally wins because of extra compounding time.

quiz3.title: Quick Check 3
quiz3.question: All else equal, which grows savings faster over time?

A.rationale: Annual compounding adds interest once per year, which is slower than monthly at the same nominal rate.

B.rationale: Correct. More frequent compounding (monthly) adds interest sooner, so it compounds slightly faster than annual.

C.rationale: 12% annually vs 10% monthly ‚Äî the higher rate (12%) generally wins despite frequency.

D.text: Both A and B are identical.
D.rationale: Frequency matters. At the same nominal rate, monthly compounding grows a bit more than annual.

quiz4.title: Quick Check 4
quiz4.question: True or False: With compounding, doubling the time generally more than doubles the final amount.

A.rationale: Correct. Compound growth is exponential ‚Äî more time lets interest earn on interest, so growth accelerates.

B.rationale: That would be closer to simple (linear) growth. Compounding accelerates over time, so longer periods can produce more-than-linear gains.

compoundingIntermediate.title: Compounding Intermediate: Rate, Frequency & Contributions
compoundingIntermediate.description: Go beyond the basics: Effective Annual Rate (EAR), why frequency matters, how recurring contributions change growth, and how compounding works against you in debt.

intro.title: From Basics to Better Decisions
intro.content: You know compound interest grows ‚Äúinterest on interest.‚Äù Now we‚Äôll use that to make practical choices: compare rates properly, understand compounding frequency, and weigh monthly deposits vs once-off amounts.

ear.title: Nominal vs Effective Annual Rate (EAR)
ear.content: Banks often quote a nominal rate (e.g., 12% p.a.). If interest is added during the year (monthly/weekly), the actual yearly growth is higher. That ‚Äútrue‚Äù yearly growth is the Effective Annual Rate (EAR). Example: 12% nominal compounded monthly ‚âà 12.68% EAR.

frequency.title: Why Frequency Matters
frequency.content: More frequent compounding means interest is added sooner and itself earns interest. For the same nominal rate, monthly compounding grows a bit faster than annual; weekly a touch faster than monthly, and so on.

contributions.title: Recurring Contributions vs Once-Off
contributions.content: Regular monthly deposits (e.g., a debit order) build a habit and steadily add fuel to compounding. A large once-off deposit enjoys the full time in the market. Which is ‚Äúbetter‚Äù depends on timing, amounts, and discipline.

debt.title: When Compounding Works Against You
debt.content: Compounding helps savings grow ‚Äî but it also makes debt more expensive over time. Paying only the minimum on a high-interest card stretches the term and increases total interest paid significantly.

quiz1.title: Quick Check 1
quiz1.question: What does the Effective Annual Rate (EAR) represent?

A.rationale: Nominal excludes the effect of intra-year compounding. EAR includes it.

B.text: The actual yearly growth including intra-year compounding.
B.rationale: Yes. EAR captures the true yearly growth once compounding frequency is considered.

C.text: The lowest possible rate after fees.
C.rationale: EAR isn‚Äôt ‚Äúlowest after fees.‚Äù It‚Äôs about compounding, not fees.

D.text: A rate that ignores compounding frequency.
D.rationale: EAR is specifically about accounting for compounding frequency.

quiz2.title: Quick Check 2
quiz2.question: Which typically yields the higher end balance (same nominal 12%)?

A.rationale: Annual is slower because interest is added only once per year.

B.rationale: Monthly adds interest more often, so it slightly outperforms annual at the same nominal rate.

C.rationale: Frequency changes the growth even if the nominal rate is the same.

D.text: Depends only on the principal, not frequency
D.rationale: Frequency matters: more frequent compounding tends to grow more.

quiz3.title: Quick Check 3
quiz3.question: You have two choices over 5 years at 8% per year: (1) deposit R500 every month, or (2) deposit R30,000 once today. Which typically ends with more?

A.text: R500 monthly (total is the same, so results are the same).
A.rationale: Totals aren‚Äôt enough ‚Äî timing matters. Monthly deposits start small and build; a lump sum compounds the full time.

B.text: R30,000 once today (it compounds for the full 5 years).
B.rationale: A lump sum placed earlier enjoys compounding for longer, usually beating equal monthly totals.

C.text: Both end equal because totals match.
C.rationale: Even with equal totals, earlier money compounds longer and usually wins.

D.rationale: Fees can matter, but ignoring fees the earlier lump sum typically wins.

quiz4.title: Quick Check 4
quiz4.question: Which statement about minimum payments on high-interest debt is most accurate?

A.rationale: Minimums often barely cover interest; total interest can stay high or climb.

B.text: They can extend the term and increase total interest paid.
B.rationale: Correct. Minimum-only strategies lengthen payoff time and increase interest cost.

C.text: They have no effect on total interest.
C.rationale: They do ‚Äî paying only minimums usually increases total interest over the life of the debt.

D.text: They are always better than extra repayments.
D.rationale: Extra repayments reduce principal faster and cut interest sooner.

quiz5.title: Quick Check 5
quiz5.question: Using the ‚ÄúRule of 72‚Äù, roughly how long to double money at 9% per year?

C.rationale: Too long for 9% using the Rule of 72.

D.rationale: Far too long for 9% using the Rule of 72.
